newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: POLICE CHARGE FIVE IN CZECH BANK FRAUD SCHEME-CTK.
newsitem.headline: POLICE CHARGE FIVE IN CZECH BANK FRAUD SCHEME-CTK.

text.p: Czech police on Friday charged five executives of the failed Kreditni Banka a.s. in a fraud scheme which caused losses totalling at least 2.88 billion crowns ($108.6 million), the Czech agency CTK said,
The executives, who were not named, were detained and charged on Friday, CTK reported quoting a state prosecutor in the western city of Plzen.
The bank's licence was withdrawn by the Czech National Bank in August with losses estimated at nearly 12 billion crowns.

The failure of Kreditni Banka, a medium-sized bank based in Plzen, caused a political furore over bank supervision, and led the government to create a special commission of ministers to lead an investigation into the case.
The agency quoted Plzen regional prosecutor Augustin Hrboticky as saying that the executives were charged with fraud, damage to creditors, and abetting fraud.
He said that investigators had identified accounts to which the 2.88 billion crowns in embezzled funds had been assigned.
No further details were immediately available.
Kreditni was the 11th of the country's then-over 50 banks to fail.

Local media reports have placed the blame for the failure of Kreditni Banka, majority owned by the largest insurer Ceska Pojistovna a.s. , on a series of murky loans made to interests connected to shareholders.
Pojistovna, which took majority stake in Kreditni in 1994, when the bank was reportedly already in a bad situation, has said it was liable for a total of nearly six billion crowns lost at Kreditni.
Kreditni's shareholders, after the central bank shut it in August, voted to liquidate the bank.

Czech National Bank Governor Josef Tosovsky, who is a member of the cabinet's investigation team which also includes the finance, justice, and interior ministers, said earlier on Friday that the country's banking system was still solid.
He said the four largest banks, where over 70 percent of activity is centred, were in much better shape than ever before in the former Communist economy's transition.
But Tosovsky that the media and political reaction to Kreditni's failure in August had temporarily destabilised the banking sector and caused a shortage in liquidity.
Tosovsky on Friday also supported opposition's call for forming of a parliamentary commission which would also probe into Kreditni's failure. ($ = 26.53 Czech Crowns)
